awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Water Oxidation by Homogeneous Manganese Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Jeremy M. Smith, Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, Indiana University, investigates how well-defined manganese catalysts convert water into oxygen. Nature has learned to convert water to oxygen using visible light. This process is called photosynthesis and uses manganese in a complicated biological protein. In this project, smaller managanese compounds are being studied both to provide basic information on photosynthetic oxygen formation and to provide new catalysts, based on inexpensive, abundant metals, for use in the laboratory or by the chemical industry. An important part of the project involves the training of students in bioinorganic and energy chemistry.
 
This project utilizes synthetic, spectroscopic and physical studies to investigate the mechanism of water oxidation by manganese macrocyclic complexes. The modular catalyst design allows for the introduction of functional groups, enabling systematic studies into the effect of proton and hydrogen atom transport as well as metal cofactors on catalyst performance. A family of manganese pyridinophane compounds serve as functional models for the oxygen evolving complex of Photosystem II. This work sets out to: (1) experimentally validate a computationally-proposed mechanism for water oxidation by these complexes, (2) determine the impact of pyridinophane stereoelectronic properties on catalytic selectivity and activity, and (3) delineate the effect of the second coordination sphere on catalytic activity, including the presence of proton and hydrogen atom relays, and redox-innocent metals. Spectroscopic, reactivity and mechanistic investigations of these species provide insights relevant to the biological water oxidation mechanism, particularly the key O-O bond forming step. Compounds are characterized by standard physical methods of X-ray diffraction, NMR, EPR, and IR, while catalytic behavior is investigated by a combination of electrochemical measurements and standard mechanistic probes.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit

This project focused on research that utilizes synthetic, spectroscopic, and physical studies in inorganic chemistry to investigate the mechanisms of: (1) water oxidation by well-defined molecular manganese catalysts, and (2) nitrogen oxide reduction by cobalt and chromium compounds. These transformations occur in aqueous solution, which provides a foundation for applying these processes to real-world environments. In addition, these transformations are driven by electrical energy, which provides a platform for developing solar-energy driven catalysis.

1. Water oxidation

The oxygen-evolving properties of a series of manganese compounds were investigated to delineate structure/function relationships. These compounds catalyze the formation of oxygen hydrogen peroxide disproportionation or by water oxidation. Here, we changed the size of the groups surrounding manganese to modify the space around the metal ion. A series of structural, spectroscopic, electrochemical, and catalytic studies established that larger groups favored water oxidation, while smaller groups favored hydrogen peroxide disproportionation. Since manganese-based hydrogen peroxide disproportionation catalysts are relatively common, whereas manganese-based water oxidation electrocatalysts are less common, this result establishes a template for creating new water oxidation electrocatalysts by simple modification of known hydrogen peroxide disproportionation catalysts.

2. Nitrogen oxide reduction

Although its reduction is thermodynamically favorable, it is a poor substrate, and there are few molecular catalysts for electrocatalytic nitrate reduction. Thus, the design principles for homogeneous nitrate reduction electrocatalysts are still lacking. To address this, we conducted investigations into the reaction mechanisms of two previously reported nitrate reduction electrocatalysts. By understanding how these catalysts work, we anticipate we will discover design principles leading to new catalysts having improved performance.

A combined experimental and computational investigation into the mechanism nitrate and nitrite reduction by Co(DIM)Br2+ reveals three important design features: (1) the catalyst is able to store two electrons, one the central metal and the supporting ligand, which allows it to mediate two-electron bond-cleavage steps without needing to access very low oxidation states; (2) the flexibility of the supporting ligand allows it to fold in such a way that the nitrate substrate can bind to the metal at two positions, thereby increasing the affinity of the catalyst for the weakly interacting nitrate anion; and (3) proton shuttles in the ligand lower the barrier for proton transfer as well as help stabilize reaction intermediates. An important aspect of the mechanism is that the substrate remains bound to the metal throughout and is only released once it is reduced to ammonia.

A similar investigation into a different molecular catalyst, Cr(cyclam)Cl2+ revealed a different mechanism. For this complex, the nature of the electrode is critical to successful catalysis. We propose that the electrode material interacts with the molecule and helps stabilize a catalytically active conformations of the catalyst. In contrast to Co(DIM)Br2+, the greater oxophilicity of chromium results in oxygen atom abstraction from nitrate to provide a chromium oxo intermediate, releasing nitrite into solution. Thus, this catalyst allows intermediate oxidation states of nitrogen oxides to prepared. Based on these results, we hypothesize that appropriate catalyst design will allow the product selectivity to be tailored.

Broader Impacts

The broader impacts of this work include the potential societal benefits from the discovery of water oxidation catalysts and nitrate reduction catalysts that are based on earth abundant metals. Efficient water oxidation is important for future energy demands, while aqueous nitrate formed by the oxidation of ammonia-based fertilizers is associated the growing number of aquatic dead zones. The mechanistic insights gained in this project provide a foundation for the design of improved catalysts that address these important probems. Students have received training in inorganic synthesis and mechanism, coupled with spectroscopic and electrochemical analysis that is relevant to important problems in bioinorganic, energy and environmental chemistry. 

 


Last Modified: 07/16/2020
Modified by: Jeremy M Smith
